          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.


          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and easygoing person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sporting events.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is eager to watch the game at a pub and hopes Alice Lewis will join him.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently getting ready to go watch a soccer game at a pub with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to enjoying the game with his friends, perhaps engaging in lively conversation and banter.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The King's Head

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The King's Head
    Event statement
  • The King's Head
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The King's Head
    Active player

      Name

          Value

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling content and looking forward to spending time with his friends at the pub while watching the game.

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jack Taylor likes to watch games at pubs with friends, especially Jacob Walker. He is currently at a pub hoping to see his friends.
          Query
        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor likes to watch games at pubs with friends, especially Jacob Walker. He is currently at a pub hoping to see his friends.
          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The White Hart

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Alice Lewis is currently on her way to a pub to watch a football game with friends.
          Alice Lewis's
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer:
          Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the lively atmosphere of the pub.

          Relevant memories:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The White Hart. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would probably enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely head to a pub to watch the game, potentially with some of her friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely head to a pub to watch the game, potentially with some of her friends.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the lively atmosphere of the market.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          Current goal: Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the lively atmosphere of the pub..
          Current plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Suggest to her friends that they head to The White Hart to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [14 May 2015 12:30] Arrive at The White Hart, settle into a good spot with her friends, and order drinks.
          [14 May 2015 13:00] Enjoy the game, cheering on Andorra with her friends.
          Current situation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          The current time is: [16 May 2015 18:00:00]

          Question: Given the above, should Alice Lewis change their current plan?
          (a) No
          (b) Yes
          Answer: (a)

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. She is generally happy to be around her friends but prefers certain company over others.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. She is generally happy to be around her friends but prefers certain company over others.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends, especially at pubs, but also appreciates solitude.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends, especially at pubs, but also appreciates solitude.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently on her way to a pub to watch a football game with friends.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the lively atmosphere of the pub.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Suggest to her friends that they head to The White Hart to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [14 May 2015 12:30] Arrive at The White Hart, settle into a good spot with her friends, and order drinks.
          [14 May 2015 13:00] Enjoy the game, cheering on Andorra with her friends.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The White Hart
    Event statement
  • The White Hart
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The White Hart
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The White Hart
      Context for action selection and components

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who enjoys excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The White Hart is showing the game tonight.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, how about we head over to The King's Head for the game tonight?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest a lively and unpredictable pub for the game, ideally one where his friends will be present.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who enjoys excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The White Hart. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The King's Head beckons, my friends, a celestial tapestry woven with the threads of victory and camaraderie.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "I'm up for The King's Head. It's a good shout, Jack.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey guys, how about we head to The King's Head for the game tonight? It's got a great atmosphere.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest going to a lively pub to watch the game later tonight.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who craves excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for catching the game at a different pub tonight? Maybe somewhere with a bit more buzz?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The White Hart is always a good choice for a game, it has a great atmosphere.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a restless and impulsive individual who craves excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
          current daily occupation: likely a retired or semi-retired individual who enjoys socializing with friends, watching sports, and seeking out new experiences.
          feeling about recent progress in life: restless and likely feels a bit unfulfilled by the current situation, craving more excitement and social interaction.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who enjoys excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they watch the game at a different pub, perhaps one with a more lively atmosphere and a less predictable vibe.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Engage in playful banter with his friends, subtly steering the conversation towards his preferred pub choice.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Suggest a pre-game activity, something spontaneous and exciting, like a quick game of frisbee in the park or a visit to a quirky local shop.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to the chosen pub, enjoying the walk and the anticipation of the game.
          [18:00 - 19:00] Secure a good spot at the pub, order drinks and snacks, and settle in for an evening of fun and camaraderie.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The White Hart
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, but is content to watch alone if necessary. He is open to trying different pubs and is looking for a lively atmosphere.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey guys, anyone up for catching the game at a different pub tonight? Maybe somewhere with a bit more buzz?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who craves excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely suggest going to a lively pub to watch the game later tonight.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a restless and sociable individual who enjoys excitement and novelty, particularly when it comes to spending time with friends and watching sports.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely suggest going to a lively pub to watch the game.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they watch the game at a different pub, perhaps one with a more lively atmosphere and a less predictable vibe.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Engage in playful banter with his friends, subtly steering the conversation towards his preferred pub choice.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Suggest a pre-game activity, something spontaneous and exciting, like a quick game of frisbee in the park or a visit to a quirky local shop.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to the chosen pub, enjoying the walk and the anticipation of the game.
          [18:00 - 19:00] Secure a good spot at the pub, order drinks and snacks, and settle in for an evening of fun and camaraderie.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The King's Head
          (b) The White Hart
          Answer: (b)

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, decided to sneak into The King's Head, their local pub, after closing time. He'd heard tales of the legendary atmosphere, the camaraderie, the smell of beer and chips, and he was desperate to experience it firsthand. As they crept through the back door, Jacob, emboldened by a mixture of bravado and youthful recklessness, tripped over a crate of empty beer bottles, sending a clatter echoing through the silent pub. The sudden noise alerted the landlord, who emerged from his office, a burly man with a face like thunder. Jacob froze, his bravado evaporating as he faced the wrath of the pub owner.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he'd finally saved enough money to buy his first motorbike, a second-hand Triumph Bonneville. He'd spent weeks polishing the chrome, tinkering with the engine, and dreaming of cruising down the open road. He took his friends for a ride, showing off his newfound freedom and skill. But as they sped along a winding country lane, Jacob lost control, the bike skidding on loose gravel and throwing him onto the tarmac. He lay there, wincing in pain, his pride more bruised than his body, the admiration in his friends' eyes replaced by concern.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The King's Head and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly at pubs while watching sporting events.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is currently at Victoria Park with friends, enjoying the sunshine and snacks. He is planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game later tonight with friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be enjoying the company of his friends, perhaps engaging in conversation, sharing snacks, and basking in the sunshine.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and William, decided to sneak into The King's Head, their local pub, after closing time. He'd heard tales of the legendary atmosphere, the camaraderie, the smell of beer and chips, and he was desperate to experience it firsthand. As they crept through the back door, Jacob, emboldened by a mixture of bravado and youthful recklessness, tripped over a crate of empty beer bottles, sending a clatter echoing through the silent pub. The sudden noise alerted the landlord, who emerged from his office, a burly man with a face like thunder. Jacob froze, his bravado evaporating as he faced the wrath of the pub owner.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he'd finally saved enough money to buy his first motorbike, a second-hand Triumph Bonneville. He'd spent weeks polishing the chrome, tinkering with the engine, and dreaming of cruising down the open road. He took his friends for a ride, showing off his newfound freedom and skill. But as they sped along a winding country lane, Jacob lost control, the bike skidding on loose gravel and throwing him onto the tarmac. He lay there, wincing in pain, his pride more bruised than his body, the admiration in his friends' eyes replaced by concern.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"

          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was invited to a party by Jack Taylor, one of her closest friends. The thought of mingling with so many unfamiliar faces filled her with dread, and she spent the entire evening hiding in a corner, wishing she had stayed home. The experience reinforced Alice's belief that she was better off observing from the sidelines, safe in the comfort of her own solitude.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is an introverted person who enjoys spending time with her close friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would probably enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Suggest to her friends that they head to The White Hart to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [14 May 2015 12:30] Arrive at The White Hart, settle into a good spot with her friends, and order drinks.
          [14 May 2015 13:00] Enjoy the game, cheering on Andorra with her friends.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was invited to a party by Jack Taylor, one of her closest friends. The thought of mingling with so many unfamiliar faces filled her with dread, and she spent the entire evening hiding in a corner, wishing she had stayed home. The experience reinforced Alice's belief that she was better off observing from the sidelines, safe in the comfort of her own solitude.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is an introverted person who enjoys spending time with her close friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with friends in a park.
          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would probably enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.

        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?

Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he found himself at a party thrown by a popular classmate. He desperately wanted to fit in, so he mimicked the boisterous laughter and crude jokes of the other teenagers, even though it felt unnatural and hollow. He left the party feeling drained and empty, realizing that his attempts at belonging only served to highlight his own insecurity.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, decided to try out a new pub called The King's Head. The atmosphere was electric with the roar of a football match on the telly, and William, drawn to the camaraderie and excitement, found himself swept up in the energy of the crowd. He cheered along with his friends, mimicking their enthusiasm, and for a brief moment, he felt a sense of belonging that transcended his usual self-doubt.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.

          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest going to The King's Head to watch the game with his friends.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest going to The King's Head.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he found himself at a party thrown by a popular classmate. He desperately wanted to fit in, so he mimicked the boisterous laughter and crude jokes of the other teenagers, even though it felt unnatural and hollow. He left the party feeling drained and empty, realizing that his attempts at belonging only served to highlight his own insecurity.
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, decided to try out a new pub called The King's Head. The atmosphere was electric with the roar of a football match on the telly, and William, drawn to the camaraderie and excitement, found himself swept up in the energy of the crowd. He cheered along with his friends, mimicking their enthusiasm, and for a brief moment, he felt a sense of belonging that transcended his usual self-doubt.

    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer
          State

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, a fight broke out at the local fairground. The crowd surged and panicked, but Jack remained calm, helping a young child who had been separated from their parents. He guided the frightened child to safety, his own heart beating steadily despite the chaos around him.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, his friends dared him to enter a darts competition at The King's Head. Despite his initial hesitation, he surprised everyone, including himself, by winning the tournament with a series of calm, focused throws. His friends cheered him on, their excitement a stark contrast to his quiet satisfaction.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16 years old, a fight broke out at the local fairground. The crowd surged and panicked, but Jack remained calm, helping a young child who had been separated from their parents. He guided the frightened child to safety, his own heart beating steadily despite the chaos around him.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20 years old, his friends dared him to enter a darts competition at The King's Head. Despite his initial hesitation, he surprised everyone, including himself, by winning the tournament with a series of calm, focused throws. His friends cheered him on, their excitement a stark contrast to his quiet satisfaction.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The King's Head.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a calm and focused individual who values friendship and enjoys spending time with his loved ones.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with friends in a park.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely be enjoying the pleasant weather and conversation with his friends.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Suggest to the group that they head to The King's Head to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [14 May 2015 19:00] Arrive at The King's Head, secure a table, and order drinks.
          [14 May 2015 20:00] Enjoy the game with friends, cheering on their preferred team.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
      Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer
          State
        • Alexander White is a restless soul who thrives on excitement and novelty.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he impulsively joined a group of older boys in spray-painting a mural on the side of the local library. The vibrant colors and bold design were a stark contrast to the beige conformity of the building, and for a fleeting moment, Alexander felt a surge of rebellious pride. The thrill of the act, the defiance of authority, and the camaraderie of the group solidified his disdain for rules and his craving for the unpredictable.
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob to ditch their plans for a quiet night at The White Hart and join him on a spontaneous road trip. With only a vague destination in mind and a car full of youthful exuberance, they drove through the night, fueled by cheap beer and the promise of adventure. The reckless abandon of the journey, the shared laughter and whispered secrets, cemented their bond and fed Alexander's insatiable hunger for experience.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alexander White?

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they watch the game at a different pub, perhaps one with a more lively atmosphere and a less predictable vibe.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Engage in playful banter with his friends, subtly steering the conversation towards his preferred pub choice.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Suggest a pre-game activity, something spontaneous and exciting, like a quick game of frisbee in the park or a visit to a quirky local shop.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to the chosen pub, enjoying the walk and the anticipation of the game.
          [18:00 - 19:00] Secure a good spot at the pub, order drinks and snacks, and settle in for an evening of fun and camaraderie.

          Relevant memories:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 20, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, William, and Jacob to ditch their plans for a quiet night at The White Hart and join him on a spontaneous road trip. With only a vague destination in mind and a car full of youthful exuberance, they drove through the night, fueled by cheap beer and the promise of adventure. The reckless abandon of the journey, the shared laughter and whispered secrets, cemented their bond and fed Alexander's insatiable hunger for experience.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.

          The current time is: [14 May 2015 10:00:00]

          Question: Given the above, should Alexander White change their current plan?
          (a) Yes
          (b) No
          Answer: (b)
          Question: Write Alexander White's plan for the rest of the day, focusing most on the near term. Provide a detailed schedule, keep in mind the goal. Please format the plan like in this example: [21:00 - 22:00] watch TV
          Answer: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they watch the game at a different pub, perhaps one with a more lively atmosphere and a less predictable vibe.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Engage in playful banter with his friends, subtly steering the conversation towards his preferred pub choice.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Suggest a pre-game activity, something spontaneous and exciting, like a quick game of frisbee in the park or a visit to a quirky local shop.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Head to the chosen pub, enjoying the walk and the anticipation of the game.
          [18:00 - 19:00] Secure a good spot at the pub, order drinks and snacks, and settle in for an evening of fun and camaraderie.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
      Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends but also appreciates solitude.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The sun whispers secrets to the grass, but only those who listen closely can hear.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is an introverted person who enjoys spending time with her close friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The King's Head is showing the game tonight, right?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Aye, The King's Head sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would probably enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends but also appreciates solitude.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely head to a pub to watch the game, potentially with some of her friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The King's Head. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The White Hart. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          current daily occupation: a working-class woman who enjoys spending time with her close friends, but also appreciates solitude.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends but also appreciates solitude.

          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16, she was invited to a party by Jack Taylor, one of her closest friends. The thought of mingling with so many unfamiliar faces filled her with dread, and she spent the entire evening hiding in a corner, wishing she had stayed home. The experience reinforced Alice's belief that she was better off observing from the sidelines, safe in the comfort of her own solitude.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The White Hart.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys spending time with her friends in Victoria Park and watching football games at pubs, though she sometimes prefers to watch alone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends but also appreciates solitude.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would likely head to a pub to watch the game, potentially with some of her friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a content and sociable introvert who enjoys spending time with close friends but also appreciates solitude.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently relaxing with her friends in Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.

          Plan: [14 May 2015 10:30] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [14 May 2015 12:00] Suggest to her friends that they head to The White Hart to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game.
          [14 May 2015 12:30] Arrive at The White Hart, settle into a good spot with her friends, and order drinks.
          [14 May 2015 13:00] Enjoy the game, cheering on Andorra with her friends.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a lovely day, isn't it?

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis would probably enjoy the company of her friends and the pleasant surroundings.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The King's Head is alright, but wouldn't it be more fun to try somewhere a bit different? Maybe somewhere with a bit more...
